clinical_study.brief_title: Association Between Telomere Length and Risk of Acute Coronary Syndrome
clinical_study.official_title: Short Telomere Length in Peripheral Blood Leukocyte Predicts the Risk of Acute Coronary Syndrome

brief_summary.textblock: Compelling epidemiological evidence indicates that alterations length of telomere, are associated with the initiation and development of ischemic heart disease. This study was undertaken to investigate whether mtDNA copy number in peripheral blood leukocyte could be used as a risk predictor for acute coronary syndrome.

primary_outcome.time_frame: From date of percutaneous coronary intervention until the date of discharging from hospital, assessed up to 5 days
primary_outcome.description: the ratio of telomere repeat copy number(T) to the hemoglobin(HGB) copy number (S) was determined for each sample using standard curves. The derived T/S ratio was proportional to the relative telomere length(RTL). In the second step, the T/S ratio of each sample was normalized to a calibrator DNA to standardize between different PCR runs. The calibrated T/S ratio was then used as the measurement of RTL in this study.

arm_group.description: 200 consecutive patients were recruited, who have diagnosed with acute coronary syndrom(ACS) by quantitative coronary angiography.
The 200 healthy controls without previous CHD history were recruited from individuals who visited investigator's hospital for physical examination during the same time period as the case enrollment.

biospec_descr.textblock: Telomeres consist of a tandem TTAGG repeat located at ends of linear chromosomes of eukaryote cells that often decrease in length over time (largely due to oxidative damage and the end replication problem during cell division) and may trigger cellular senescence once telomere become critically short

study_pop.textblock: A total of 200 eligible ACS patients were anticipated to include in this study.Moreover, The 200 healthy controls without previous CHD history were also recruited from individuals who visited investigator's hospital for physical examination during the same time period.
